title: The Role of an Inciting Event Causing Vertigo
chief_complaint: I hear my own voice abnormally loud in my head (autophony). This started after a scuba diving trip 5 months ago.

problem_summary.onset: Abrupt onset 5 months ago during a scuba dive.
problem_summary.course: Initial vertigo and otalgia resolved; autophony persists.
problem_summary.laterality: Right-sided hearing loss and otalgia initially; autophony is the primary current symptom.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: History of URI and difficulty auto-insufflating (Valsalva) during the dive. Vertigo triggered by loud sounds (during testing).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Disturbing sensation of hearing own voice loudly.

history.present_illness: Patient experienced right-sided hearing loss, otalgia, and vertigo while scuba diving 5 months ago. She was recovering from a URI and had trouble equalizing pressure. Post-dive, she noticed autophony. Otalgia and vertigo resolved, but autophony remains.
history.otologic_history: No evidence of middle ear fluid or nasopharyngeal mass on physical exam.
history.medical_psych_history: Recovering from URI at time of incident.
history.prior_management: Referred to otolaryngology; physical exam was normal.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows a slight conductive hearing loss at 250 Hz (air-bone gap) with normal hearing 500-8000 Hz. Left ear shows slight sensorineural hearing loss.

numeric_results.Right AC Thresholds: 25 dB HL at 250 Hz, 10 dB at 500 Hz, 5 dB at 1000-2000 Hz
numeric_results.Right BC Thresholds: 5 dB HL at 250 Hz (approx 20 dB Air-Bone Gap)

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ability to recognize speech in both ears. SRT aligns with PTA.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, middle ear pressure, and static admittance (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present at normal sensation levels. CRITICAL FINDING: Patient reported vertigo during ART testing at 500 and 1000 Hz (Tullio's phenomenon).

history.present_illness: Follow-up to investigate suspected third-window pathology based on V1 findings (air-bone gap with normal tymps + Tullio's phenomenon).

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Noncontrast temporal bone CT scan reveals bilateral Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD). No evidence of Enlarged Vestibular Aqueduct (EVA) or other masses.

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation reveals a slight low-frequency conductive hearing loss in the right ear (specifically a 250 Hz air-bone gap) despite normal tympanometry. The left ear shows slight sensorineural hearing loss. Speech recognition is excellent bilaterally. A critical finding is the report of vertigo induced by loud sounds during acoustic reflex testing (Tullio's phenomenon). Combined with the history of barotrauma, these findings are highly consistent with third-window pathology, specifically Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD), which was subsequently confirmed by CT imaging.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a specific pattern: a 'gap' between your hearing nerve function and how sound travels through the ear at low pitches, even though your middle ear system (eardrum) is moving normally.
You experienced dizziness when we played loud sounds during the test. This is called Tullio's phenomenon and suggests a 'third window' or opening in the inner ear bone.

The CT scan confirmed a thinning or opening in the bone of the superior semicircular canal (SSCD). This explains why you hear your voice so loudly (autophony)â€”sound is escaping through this extra opening.
The scuba diving incident, combined with the pressure from your cold, likely caused this thin bone to open.
We will discuss management options with the otologist, which may include avoiding triggers (like pressure changes or loud noises) or surgical repair if symptoms are debilitating.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is annoyed by the sound of their own voice (autophony).
When the audiologist performs the Acoustic Reflex test (loud beeps), you should complain of sudden, brief dizziness or spinning.
Emphasize that the symptoms started exactly during the dive when you were struggling to clear your ears.
